questions.text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Obstetric conjugate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet
  • ➤ Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet
  • ➤ Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter
  • ➤ Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. Obstetric conjugate (10 cm): It is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet and hence obstetrically most important. It is measured from the middle of sacral promontory to symphysis pubis. It cannot be measured directly on clinical examination. It is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate. Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): It is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis. It is the only diameter that can be assessed clinically.
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.
  • ➤ True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm):
  • ➤ Obstetric conjugate (10 cm): It is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet and hence obstetrically most important. It is measured from the middle of sacral promontory to symphysis pubis. It cannot be measured directly on clinical examination. It is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate.
  • ➤ Obstetric conjugate (10 cm):
  • ➤ Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): It is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis. It is the only diameter that can be assessed clinically.

  • ➤ Transverse Diameter (13 cm)

questions.text: Engagement is defined as:

options.label: B
options.text: When the largest transverse diameter of the fetal head, the bitemporal diameter enters the pelvic mid cavity

options.label: C
options.text: When the largest transverse diameter of the fetal head, the biparietal diameter enters the pelvic inlet

options.text: When the largest transverse diameter of the fetal head, the bitemporal diameter enters the pelvic mid cavity

questions.text: When the anterior parietal bone of the fetus descends first into the pelvis during engagement, it is called?

Posterior asynclitism (Litzman asynclitism): When the posterior parietal bone enters 1 st (More common in Primigravidas)
  • ➤ Asynclitism is when the engagement is not symmetrical and one parietal bone enters the pelvic inlet first
  • ➤ Anterior asynclitism (Nagele’s asynclitism): When the anterior parietal bone enters 1 st .

questions.text: If the fetus enters the pelvis with its sagittal suture in the transverse diameter of the pelvis, internal rotation will happen by how many degrees?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 90˚

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In left or right occipito anterior positions, the internal rotation will be by 45˚, so that the occiput comes to lie anteriorly In left or right occipito transverse, the internal rotation will be by 90˚, so that the occiput comes to lie anteriorly In right or right occipito posterior positions, there could either be Internal rotation anteriorly by 135˚ (long arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie anteriorly OR Internal rotation anteriorly by 135˚ (long arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie in the antero-posterior diameter OR Internal rotation posteriorly by 45˚ (short arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie in the posteriorly
  • ➤ In left or right occipito anterior positions, the internal rotation will be by 45˚, so that the occiput comes to lie anteriorly
  • ➤ In left or right occipito transverse, the internal rotation will be by 90˚, so that the occiput comes to lie anteriorly
  • ➤ In right or right occipito posterior positions, there could either be Internal rotation anteriorly by 135˚ (long arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie anteriorly OR Internal rotation anteriorly by 135˚ (long arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie in the antero-posterior diameter OR Internal rotation posteriorly by 45˚ (short arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie in the posteriorly
  • ➤ Internal rotation anteriorly by 135˚ (long arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie anteriorly OR Internal rotation anteriorly by 135˚ (long arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie in the antero-posterior diameter OR Internal rotation posteriorly by 45˚ (short arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie in the posteriorly
  • ➤ Internal rotation anteriorly by 135˚ (long arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie anteriorly OR
  • ➤ Internal rotation anteriorly by 135˚ (long arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie in the antero-posterior diameter OR
  • ➤ Internal rotation posteriorly by 45˚ (short arc rotation), so that the occiput comes to lie in the posteriorly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ A pregnant woman with an Rh-negative blood group with a negative ICT (not iso-immunized) should not be allowed to go beyond 40 weeks, i.e. if she doesn’t go into labor, she should be induced at 40 weeks. This is to reduce the risk of feto-maternal hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 32-year G2 presents to the antenatal OPD. Her period of gestation is 40 weeks. She is planned for induction of labor. On a vaginal exam, the cervix is 2 cm dilated, 1 cm long, soft inconsistency and mid-position. The station of the fetal head is at -1. She asks if induction of labor will be successful? What will you tell her?

options.label: A
options.text: She will not respond favorably to induction of labor and will require pre-induction cervical ripening

options.label: B
options.text: She will not respond favorably to induction and LSCS should be done

options.label: C
options.text: She will respond favorably to induction of labor

options.label: D
options.text: The given information is insufficient to make a conclusion

questions.correct_answer: C. She will respond favorably to induction of labor
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. She will respond favorably to induction of labor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bishop score is as shown in the table. Each component is scored from 0 to 3 The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0 A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor.
  • ➤ The Bishop score is as shown in the table.
  • ➤ Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • ➤ The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • ➤ A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 247, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 247, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3 rd edition

questions.text: According to WHO guidelines on management of labor, which of the following is true about management of second stage of labor?

options.label: B
options.text: Episiotomy should be performed as a routine

options.label: C
options.text: A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma

options.label: D
options.text: Delivery should be ideally performed in a lithotomy position

questions.correct_answer: C. A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ As per WHO recommendations of 2018,
  • ➤ As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2 nd stage
  • ➤ As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2 nd stage
  • ➤ Definition and duration of the second stage of labor: The second stage is the period of time between full cervical dilatation and birth of the baby, during which the woman has an involuntary urge to bear down, as a result of expulsive uterine contractions. In first labors, birth is usually completed within 3 hours whereas in subsequent labors, birth is usually completed within 2 hours. Recommended Birth position (for women with or without epidural analgesia) For women without epidural analgesia, encouraging the adoption of a birth position of the individual woman’s choice, including upright positions, is recommended. Method of pushing Women in the expulsive phase of the second stage of labor should be encouraged and supported to follow their own urge to push. Method of pushing (for women with epidural analgesia) For women with epidural analgesia in the second stage of labor, delaying pushing for one to two hours after full dilatation or until the woman regains the sensory urge to bear down is recommended in the context where resources are available for longer stay in second stage and perinatal hypoxia can be adequately assessed and managed. Techniques for preventing perineal trauma. For women in the second stage of labor, techniques to reduce perineal trauma and facilitate spontaneous birth (including perineal massage, warm compresses and a “hands on” guarding of the perineum) are recommended, based on a woman’s preferences and available options. Episiotomy policy Routine or liberal use of episiotomy is not recommended for women undergoing spontaneous vaginal birth. Fundal pressure Application of manual fundal pressure to facilitate childbirth during the second stage of labor is not recommended.

questions.text: A midwife at a PHC is monitoring pregnancy and maintaining the WHO modified partograph of pregnancy progression. At how much cervical dilation should the partograph plotting be started?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 4 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor. It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention. In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. (Alert Line) Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor.
  • ➤ It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention.
  • ➤ In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated.
  • ➤ In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. (Alert Line)
  • ➤ Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate)
  • ➤ A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Remember that in the modified partograph, plotting starts at 4 cm onward, and the 1 st mark is always put on the alert line If asked, when does plotting start in the Labor care guide (Next generation partograph), then the answer is 5cm
  • ➤ Remember that in the modified partograph, plotting starts at 4 cm onward, and the 1 st mark is always put on the alert line
  • ➤ If asked, when does plotting start in the Labor care guide (Next generation partograph), then the answer is 5cm

questions.text: All are components of active management of the third stage of labor except?

options.label: A
options.text: Uterotonic agent within 1 minute of birth

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Early cord clamping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Active Management of 3 rd Stage of Labor
  • ➤ Active Management of 3 rd Stage of Labor
  • ➤ Described by the WHO in 2007 Involves mainly 3 basic steps. Administering a uterotonic Controlled cord traction Uterine massage AMTSL prevents atonic PPH. In 2012, the WHO issued new guidelines for AMTSL which essentially emphasized the main 3 things but with additional information which was Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV) Do Controlled cord traction only if a skilled birth attendant is present. Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who’ve received uterotonic; instead; postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done. Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care (This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed) In 2018, the WHO issued further guidelines on which other uterotonics can be used for AMTSL. These include: Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV) Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV) Misoprostol (400 OR 600 mcg PO – to be used where Skilled birth attendant isn’t available) Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV EXCEPT in hypertensive women)) Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM) Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH AMTSL decreases Incidence of PPH. Length of third stage of labor. Percentage of third stages of labor lasting longer than 30 minutes. Need for blood transfusion. Need for uterotonic drugs to manage PPH

questions.text: Following delivery of a 4kg baby to a mother with gestational diabetes, you note that there is a tear involving the perineum and external anal sphincter with intact mucosa. The grade of the tear is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Third degree

Explanation:

  • • Explanation and Other Options
  • • First degree: Injury to perineal skin Second degree: Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter. Third degree: Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both the external and internal). 3a: if half thickness external anal sphincter involved. 3b: if full thickness external anal sphincter involved. 3c: if internal anal sphincter involved. Fourth degree: Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (external anal sphincter and internal anal sphincter) and anal epithelium.
  • • First degree: Injury to perineal skin
  • • Second degree: Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.
  • • Third degree: Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both the external and internal). 3a: if half thickness external anal sphincter involved. 3b: if full thickness external anal sphincter involved. 3c: if internal anal sphincter involved.

questions.text: A 22-year primigravida is in labor and on examination, the cervix is 2cm dilated. The fetal heart rate is 148bpm and rises to 156 bpm for 20 seconds then falls to 142 bpm. This type of presentation is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. It’s a normal pattern

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Baseline FHR — 110-150 bpm. Baseline variability — 5-25 bpm Acceleration — 2 in 20 min Deceleration — None or early Baseline FHR is the mean level of FHR between the peaks and the depressions in beats per minute (bpm) Baseline variability is the oscillation of baseline FHR excluding the accelerations and decelerations. A baseline variability of 5-25 bpm is a sign of fetal wellbeing. Accelerations are increase in FHR by 15 bpm or more lasting for at least 15 secs. Denotes healthy fetus. Deceleration is decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more. Three basic types of decelerations are observed:
  • ➤ Baseline FHR — 110-150 bpm.
  • ➤ Baseline variability — 5-25 bpm
  • ➤ Acceleration — 2 in 20 min
  • ➤ Deceleration — None or early
  • ➤ Baseline FHR is the mean level of FHR between the peaks and the depressions in beats per minute (bpm)
  • ➤ Baseline variability is the oscillation of baseline FHR excluding the accelerations and decelerations.
  • ➤ A baseline variability of 5-25 bpm is a sign of fetal wellbeing.
  • ➤ Accelerations are increase in FHR by 15 bpm or more lasting for at least 15 secs. Denotes healthy fetus.
  • ➤ Deceleration is decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more. Three basic types of decelerations are observed:
  • ➤ Non-stress test (NST): continuous electronic monitoring of fetal heart
  • ➤ Reactive (Reassuring): 2 or more contractions of more than 15 bpm above the baseline and longer than 15seconds in duration are present in a 20-minute observation. Non-Reactive (Non-Reassuring): absence of fetal reactivity, Perinatal death rate of 40/1000.
  • ➤ Reactive (Reassuring): 2 or more contractions of more than 15 bpm above the baseline and longer than 15seconds in duration are present in a 20-minute observation.
  • ➤ Non-Reactive (Non-Reassuring): absence of fetal reactivity, Perinatal death rate of 40/1000.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1138, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1138, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which are features of false labor? Steady intensity of pain Cervical dilation Discomfort is in the back and abdomen Intervals remain long Discomfort usually is relieved by sedation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A, D, E

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Characteristic of True & False Labor
  • • Characteristic of True & False Labor
  • • True Labor
  • • True Labor
  • • Contractions occur at regular intervals. Intervals gradually shorten. Intensity gradually increases. Discomfort is in the back and abdomen. Cervix dilates. Discomfort is not stopped by sedation.
  • • Contractions occur at regular intervals.
  • • Intervals gradually shorten.
  • • Intensity gradually increases.
  • • Discomfort is in the back and abdomen.
  • • Cervix dilates.
  • • Discomfort is not stopped by sedation.
  • • False Labor
  • • False Labor
  • • Contractions occur at irregular intervals. Intervals remain long. Intensity remains unchanged. Discomfort is chiefly in the lower abdomen. Cervix does not dilate. Discomfort usually is relieved by sedation.
  • • Contractions occur at irregular intervals.
  • • Intervals remain long.
  • • Intensity remains unchanged.
  • • Discomfort is chiefly in the lower abdomen.
  • • Cervix does not dilate.
  • • Discomfort usually is relieved by sedation.
  • • Thus A, D and E are seen in false labor correct answer is option B) A, D, E

questions.text: A midwife at a PHC is monitoring pregnancy and maintaining the partograph of progression of labor of a 22y primigravida. At how much cervical dilation should the WHO modified partograph plotting be started?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 4 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Partograph
  • ➤ Partograph
  • ➤ The WHO modified Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labour, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labour. It is used for early detection of abnormal labour patterns for timely intervention. In a partograph the active phase of labour starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation. Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ The WHO modified Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labour, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labour.
  • ➤ It is used for early detection of abnormal labour patterns for timely intervention.
  • ➤ In a partograph the active phase of labour starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr.
  • ➤ Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation. Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate)
  • ➤ Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ The WHO has now introduced the WHO Labor care guide in 2018 where several changes have been made. This is also called the “Next generation partograph”. In this, the active labor starts at 5cm.
  • ➤ The WHO has now introduced the WHO Labor care guide in 2018 where several changes have been made. This is also called the “Next generation partograph”. In this, the active labor starts at 5cm.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 213 JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 213 JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3 rd edition
